abstract.text: An anchor for a unique face that is visible in the front-facing camera.

inlineContent.text: The session automatically adds to its list of anchors an ARFaceAnchor object when it detects a unique face in the front camera feed.
, ARKit can track multiple faces simultaneously.
Alternatively, you can enable face tracking with a world tracking configuration by setting .
property describes the face’s current position and orientation in world coordinates; that is, in a coordinate space relative to that specified by the
property of the session configuration. Use this transform matrix to position virtual content you want to “attach” to the face in your AR scene.

This transform matrix creates a face coordinates system for positioning other elements relative to the face. Units of face coordinate space are in meters, with the origin centered behind the face as indicated in the figure below.

The coordinate system is right-handed—the positive x direction points to the viewer’s right (that is, the face’s own left), the positive y direction points up (relative to the face itself, not to the world), and the positive z direction points outward from the face (toward the viewer).
object representing detailed topology for the face, which conforms a generic face model to match the dimensions, shape, and current expression of the detected face.
You can use this model as the basis for overlaying content that follows the shape of the user’s face—for example, to apply virtual makeup or tattoos. You can also use this model to create
—a 3D model that doesn’t render any visible content (allowing the camera image to show through), but that obstructs the camera’s view of other virtual content in the scene.

property provides a high-level model of the current facial expression, described via a series of many named coefficients that represent the movement of specific facial features relative to their neutral configurations. You can use blend shape coefficients to animate 2D or 3D content, such as a character or avatar, in ways that follow the user’s facial expressions.

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An object that specifies the position and orientation of an item in the physical environment.
A matrix encoding the position, orientation, and scale of the anchor relative to the world coordinate space of the AR session the anchor is placed in.
Support for custom anchor subclasses.
A value specifying how the session maps real-world device motion into a 3D scene coordinate system.
An anchor for a unique face that is visible in the front-facing camera.
Identifiers for specific facial features, for use with coefficients describing the relative movements of those features.
A dictionary of named coefficients representing the detected facial expression in terms of the movement of specific facial features.
A coarse triangle mesh representing the topology of the detected face.
A transform matrix indicating the position and orientation of the face’s left eye.
A position in face coordinate space estimating the direction of the face’s gaze.
A transform matrix indicating the position and orientation of the face’s right eye.
A 3D mesh describing face topology for use in face-tracking AR sessions.
A configuration that tracks facial movement and expressions using the front camera.
An interface for objects that track the location of real-world objects or locations.
Track the user’s face in an app that displays an AR experience with the rear camera.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Combining user face-tracking and world tracking

abstract.text: Detect faces in a front-camera AR experience, overlay virtual content, and animate facial expressions in real-time.
Discover features and best practices for building rear-camera AR experiences.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
